title: 104_hr248
content: The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section on the prevention of traumatic brain injury. The Secretary of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention may conduct projects to reduce traumatic brain injury through grants or contracts to public or nonprofit entities. Activities may include research on prevention strategies and public education programs. The Secretary coordinates activities with other Public Health Service agencies regarding traumatic brain injury. Traumatic brain injury is defined as an acquired brain injury, excluding congenital or degenerative disorders. The definition may be revised as needed. The curr_chunk states "SEC. 2. PROGRAMS OF NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH." Section 1261 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include the authority to make awards of grants or contracts for research on traumatic brain injury, including the development of new methods for diagnosis and monitoring. The amendment to Section 1261 of the Public Health Service Act includes grants for research on traumatic brain injury, focusing on therapies to reverse brain damage, continuum of care from acute care to rehabilitation, and increasing academic centers' participation in research and training. The term 'traumatic brain injury' refers to an acquired brain injury, excluding brain dysfunction from congenital or degenerative disorders and birth trauma. It may include brain injuries from anoxia due to near drowning, with the Secretary having the authority to revise the definition as needed. SEC. 1252. STATE GRANTS FOR DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS REGARDING TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY. The Secretary may make grants to States for demonstration projects to improve access to health services for traumatic brain injury. States must establish an advisory board to advise on improving services coordination. Advisory boards should encourage citizen participation through public hearings. The advisory board established under the grant program should consult with various agencies and groups, including state agencies, health organizations, disability advisory groups, traumatic brain injury survivor representatives, and injury control programs at the state or local level. The Secretary may make a grant under the program if a State agrees to provide matching funds in cash, not including federal contributions. The Secretary may grant funds for traumatic brain injury programs based on submitted applications containing necessary information. Activities must be coordinated with other Public Health Service agencies, and a report on program findings must be submitted to specific committees within 2 years. The section defines traumatic brain injury as an acquired injury to the brain, excluding congenital or degenerative disorders. The Secretary may revise the definition as needed. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1997 to 1999 for program implementation. SEC. 4. STUDY; CONSENSUS CONFERENCE. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on traumatic brain injury to determine incidence, prevalence, and develop a reporting system. They will also identify common therapeutic interventions for rehabilitation. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will analyze the effectiveness of interventions for improving brain injury functioning, compare rehabilitation interventions for similar outcomes, and develop practice guidelines when appropriate scientific research is available. The report must be submitted within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will submit reports to specified committees on findings from carrying out interventions for brain injury functioning. Additionally, a national consensus conference on managing traumatic brain injury and related rehabilitation concerns will be conducted. The term "traumatic brain injury" refers to an acquired injury to the brain, excluding brain dysfunction from congenital or degenerative disorders. The Secretary may revise this definition as needed. $3,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 1997-1999 for subsection (a)(1)(A), and an aggregate $500,000 for other provisions in the same period. Amounts appropriated for other provisions are available until expended. SEC. 5. TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. Title XXVI of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 300ff-11 et seq.), as amended by Public Law 104-146 (the Ryan White CARE Act Amendments of 1996), is amended in sections 2626 and 2692 to make changes to subsections and authorization of appropriations for programs under this title. For grants under subsection (a) and (b) of Title XXVI of the Public Health Service Act, sums are authorized to be appropriated for schools and dental schools for fiscal years 1996 through 2000.
